overview: Housing Benefit is financial help to pay all or part of your rent - check if you're entitled, how much it is, claim form and online calculator
title: Housing Benefit

table.body:
You may be able to get Housing Benefit if you're on a low income and need financial help to pay all or part of your rent.

^You could qualify whether you're working or not.^

You may also be able to get an [Extended Payment of Housing Benefit](/housing-benefit/further-information "Extended Payment of Housing Benefit"). This payment can provide help for up to an extra 4 weeks when you start a new job, or your wages or working hours increase.
table.title: Overview

table.body:
##Renting council accommodation or other social housing##

If you live in council accommodation or other social housing, the most Housing Benefit you can get is the same as your 'eligible' rent.

Eligible rent includes:

- rent for your accommodation 
- charges for some services, eg lift maintenance, communal laundry facilities or play areas 

Even if it's included in your rent, you won't get any Housing Benefit for:

- water charges 
- charges for heating, hot water, lighting, or cooking 
- payments for food or fuel in board and lodgings or hostels 

###Your circumstances###

The amount of Housing Benefit you may get also depends on your personal and financial circumstances.

Your local council will look at:

- money you and your partner or civil partner have coming in, including earnings, some benefits and tax credits, and occupational pensions 
- your savings (and your partner's or civil partner's savings) 
- your circumstances - eg your age, the size of your family and their ages, whether you or any of your family are disabled, and whether anyone who lives with you could help with the rent

###Your home and rent###

Your council will also take into account your home and the rent you pay. They'll look at whether:

- the amount of rent is reasonable for your particular home 
- your home is a reasonable size for you and your family 
- the amount of rent is reasonable for the area where you live

##Renting from a private landlord - Local Housing Allowance##

If you rent a property or room from a private landlord, the amount of Housing Benefit you get will be calculated using the Local Housing Allowance rates.

The amount you get will depend on where you live and who lives with you.

Local Housing Allowance rates are set for different types of accommodation in each area. The rates range from a single room in a shared house, up to properties with 4 bedrooms.

###Local Housing Allowance limits###

There are limits to the amount of Local Housing Allowance that can be paid:

- £250 a week for a 1 bedroom property (including shared accommodation)
- £290 a week for a 2 bedroom property
- £340 a week for a 3 bedroom property
- £400 a week for a 4 bedroom property

Find the [Local Housing Allowance rates for where you live.](http://www.direct.gov.uk/en/Diol1/DoItOnline/DG_196239 "Local Housing Allowance rates for where you live"){:rel="external"}

If you've been getting Housing Benefit since before 7 April 2008, the Local Housing Allowance rules will only apply to you if you:

- change address 
- have a break in your claim for Housing Benefit

##How Housing Benefit is paid##

If you're a council tenant, your local council will pay any Housing Benefit straight into your rent account.

If you're renting privately, your Housing Benefit will be paid:

- directly into your bank or building society account
- to you by cheque, in some circumstances
table.title: What you'll get

table.body:
You may get Housing Benefit if:

- you pay rent
- your income, savings and investments are below a certain level - usually £16,000, unless you're getting the 'guarantee credit' of Pension Credit 

You could qualify whether you’re working or not.

You can [check your eligibility for Housing Benefit](/apply-housing-benefit-from-council "Apply for Housing Benefit from your council") with your local council.

You can also get an [online estimate of the amount of Housing Benefit you might get.](http://www.direct.gov.uk/en/Diol1/DoItOnline/DoItOnlineByCategory/DG_172666 "Online estimate of Housing Benefit"){:rel="external"}

##Who isn't eligible##

You can't usually get Housing Benefit if:

- you have savings of over £16,000, unless you're getting the 'guarantee credit' of Pension Credit 
- you live in the home of a close relative 
- you're a full-time student (unless you're disabled or have children) 
- you're an asylum seeker or are sponsored to be in the UK

##Other Housing Benefit circumstances##

If you live with a partner or civil partner, only one of you can get Housing Benefit.

If you're single and aged under 35, you can only get Housing Benefit for:

- bed-sit accommodation
- a single room in shared accommodation
table.title: Eligibility

table.body:
##If you're claiming other benefits##

Contact Jobcentre Plus to claim Housing Benefit with your claim for the following benefits:

- Employment and Support Allowance
- Income Support
- Jobseeker's Allowance

$C**Jobcentre Plus**

**Telephone:** 0800 055 6688  
**Textphone:** 0800 023 4888  
**Opening hours:** Monday to Friday, 8am to 6pm$C

Jobcentre Plus will send details of your claim for Housing Benefit to your local council.

##If you’re claiming Pension Credit##

Contact the Pensions Service to claim Housing Benefit with your claim for Pension Credit.

$C**Pensions Service**

**Telephone:** 0800 99 1234  
**Textphone:** 0800 169 0133  
**Opening hours:** Monday to Friday, 8am to 8pm and Saturday, 9am to 1pm$C

The Pensions Service will send details of your claims for Housing Benefit to your local council.

##If you're not claiming other benefits##

You can make a claim for Housing Benefit directly with [your local council.](/apply-housing-benefit-from-council "Apply for Housing Benefit from your council")

You can also download a claim form (HCTB1). The form comes with notes that help you fill it in and tell you where to send it.

$D[Download 'Housing Benefit claim form HCTB1' (PDF, 179KB)](http://www.dwp.gov.uk/advisers/claimforms/hctb1_print.pdf "Housing Benefit claim form HCTB1"){:rel="external"}$D

##Claiming in advance##

You can claim Housing Benefit up to 13 weeks before you move (17 weeks if you're aged 60 or over). So if you know you're moving to a new address soon, you can claim Housing Benefit before you move. You won't usually get any money before you move in.
table.title: How to claim

table.body:
##Extended Payment of Housing Benefit##

If you're getting Housing Benefit, some of your benefits may stop if you:

- go back to work
- work more hours
- earn more money

If this happens, you may get an extra 4 weeks of Housing Benefit to help you pay your rent. This is called Extended Payment of Housing Benefit and your council decides if you can get it.

You'll normally get the same amount of Housing Benefit as you did before.

Once your Extended Payment of Housing Benefit has ended, you might be able to get 'in-work Housing Benefit'. Your local council will decide if you can get in-work Housing Benefit. You won't have to make a claim.

##If your circumstances change##

Tell your [local council](http://local.direct.gov.uk/LDGRedirect/Start.do?mode=1 "Contact your local council"){:rel="external"} straight away if your circumstances change. Some examples of the changes you need to report include:

- any of your children leave school or leave home 
- your rent changes 
- you move
- your savings change
- you or your partner are going to be away from home for more than a month

##How to appeal##

If you're refused Housing Benefit or aren't happy with your council's decision, [contact your local council](http://local.direct.gov.uk/LDGRedirect/Start.do?mode=1 "Contact your local council"){:rel="external"} and ask for an explanation. You can also ask them to reconsider.

If you're still unhappy with the outcome, you can [appeal against the Housing Benefit decision](/appeal-housing-benefit-decision "Appeal a Housing Benefit decision").
